Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Imaging Modalities for Lobular Carcinoma Detection

Trial_Design.evidence: randomised controlled trial included women aged 40-70 with suspected LC

Participants.evidence: women aged 40-70 with suspected LC. Conducted at a tertiary care center

Intervention.evidence: traditional imaging (mammography and ultrasound) and advanced imaging (MRI, DBT, CEM, BSGI)

Objective.evidence: This study assesses the effectiveness of traditional versus advanced imaging modalities in detecting LC.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was diagnostic accuracy, evaluated over a six-month period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation concealment was achieved using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group allocation, while patients and clinicians were not.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the traditional imaging group and 100 to the advanced imaging group, between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: 98 participants in the traditional group and 97 in the advanced group were analysed.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Advanced imaging demonstrated significantly higher diagnostic accuracy (mean difference = 15%, 95% CI 10% to 20%; p < 0.001).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were minimal, with 3% in the advanced group and 1% in the traditional group experiencing mild discomfort.

Funding.evidence: This trial was funded by the National Cancer Institute.
